subject: Re: [junit] Re: performance testing
msgSnippet: ... I understand... that s the fault of the programmer not using JUnit as expected. If the programmer wants JUnit to report accurate times, the programmer
messageBody:
Chad Woolley wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > Then I would override runBare() to generate more events: one after
> > setUp() and one before tearDown(), then augment TestListener, then have
> > the test monitor implement the bigger TestListener interface. All you
> > need are two more events, and since you can fix that in one place....
> >
> > It's entirely possible that JUnit-addons Test Runner already does this.
> >
> > Understand, I'm not trying to squash your enthusiasm for AOP. You just
> > have that Golden Hammer look in your eye....
>
> Yep, this does work fine, if you don't have any fixture-setup code in your
> testcase itself. However, many people haven't refactored all fixture
> code into
> setUp() and tearDown(). If this is the case, there could be some
> time-consuming
> fixture code in the test methods themselves. This would mean that checking
> times after setUp() and before tearDown() would still be counting the
> fixture
> execution time in with the Class Under Test execution time.

I understand... that's the fault of the programmer not using JUnit as
expected. If the programmer wants JUnit to report accurate times, the
programmer ought to put setup code in setUp(). :)

> Having a listener is another viable Plain Java approach, but you would
> still
> have to manually fire the listener before and after you actual
> invocation of the
> class under test. This is the type of non-refactorable duplication that
> AOP solves.

I see... that would be nice: using AOP to instrument an event source
without hardcoding when the events occur. That is neat. (I haven't
learned much about the practical use of AOP, as you might be able to tell.)

> I'm not advocating AOP in all cases, in fact I think you should try hard
> to find
> a Plain Java solution that works before resorting to AOP. I'm just
> trying to
> illustrate that it could be useful in a specific scenario: Monitoring
> execution
> time of the class under test if 1) you have fixture setup code in your test
> methods and 2) the execution time of that fixture setup code could
> obscure the
> actual execution time of the Class Under Test.

I can see the general use of AOP for generating events on behalf of an
event source. Good idea.

> Most likely this isn't the situation of the original poster, so it doesn't
> matter. We can drop this thread before people start complaining :).

Let them complain. This list is such low traffic that OT stuff is not a
problem here. :)
